anchor.surface_text: Whether the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal was bound by the findings of fact of the Income-tax Officer relating to the nature and division of the assets of the joint family in question which he arrived at in his enquiry under Section 25A of the Indian

holdings.text: when a claim is made under s. 25A, the points to be decided by the Income-tax Officer are whether there has been a partition in the family, and if so, what the definite portions are in which the division had been made among the members or groups of members. The question as to what the income of the family assessable to tax under s. 23 was, would be foreign to the scope of an enquiry under s. 25A.

anchor.surface_text: Now, when a claim is made under s. 25A, the points to be decided by the Income-tax Officer are whether there has been a partition in the family, and if so, what the definite portions are in which the division had been made among the members or groups of members. The question as to what the income of the family assessable to tax under s. 23

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory textual and purposive interpretation: s.25A introduced by 1928 Amendment to deem family undivided for tax till order, limited to partition factum and shares; s.23 assessment independent; no implication from s.25A order on income character as same officer issued both orders same day.

holdings.text: In fact, that order does not expressly decide that the family had the jewels mentioned in Ex. A, and that they were converted into cash as claimed by the appellant. Nor could such a finding be implied therein, when regard is had to the scope of the proceedings under s. 25A and to the fact that the order under s. 23 holding that the sum of Rs. 2,30,346 did not represent the value of the family jewels sold was passed on the same date as the order under s. 25A and by the very same officer.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No express or implied finding in s.25A order on jewels sale as outside scope; confirmed by contemporaneous independent s.23 order rejecting same.

holdings.text: Whatever view one might be inclined to take on the former question, so far as the latter is concerned, it is perfectly plain that they were not.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever view one might be inclined to take on the former question, so far as the latter is concerned, it is perfectly plain that they were not. On May 27, 1947, the enquiry was held on both the petitions under s, 25A and on the quantum of income assessable to tax under s. 23 3 . Exhibit D is an extract from the order sheet of the Income-tax Officer, and it runs as follows Regarding credits amounting to Rs. 2,30,346-6-3

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exhibit D order sheet shows proceedings book minutes prior to April 21 not listed or relied as evidence before ITO on credits character; only April 21 minute translated as Ex.B for partition proof.

holdings.text: In view of these facts, we are unable to hold that in refusing to admit the proceedings book as evidence in the appeal, the Appellate Tribunal acted perversely or unreasonably.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these facts, we are unable to hold that in refusing to admit the proceedings book as evidence in the appeal, the Appellate Tribunal acted perversely or unreasonably. Indeed, counsel for the appellant did not contend in the High Court that the Tribunal had acted illegally or unreasonably in refusing to admit the proceedings book in evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Book identity unproved; prior minutes not relied before ITO/AAC per records, no affidavit petition pursued; not even contended before High Court.

holdings.text: That being so, it cannot be said that the finding given by the Tribunal on an appreciation of the facts and circumstances already set out is unsupported by evidence or is perverse.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, it cannot be said that the finding given by the Tribunal on an appreciation of the facts and circumstances already set out is unsupported by evidence or is perverse. The position may thus be summed up In the business accounts of the appellant we find certain sums credited.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discrepancies in books (ornaments vs gold), weight (3422 vs 3133 tolas unexplained by alloy), round figure sales suspicious; explanation changed over appeals; proceedings book irrelevant as not relied timely.

holdings.text: There is ample authority for the position that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amounts of cash received during the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipts are of an assessable nature. That is precisely what the Income-tax authorities have done in the present case, and we do not find any grounds for holding that their finding is open to attack as erroneous in law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected explanation of credits source; per precedent (Govindarajulu Mudaliar), infer business profits taxable under IT Act and Excess Profits Tax Act.

precedents.citation: V. Govindarajulu Mudaliar v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad 1

anchor.surface_text: In V. Govindarajulu Mudaliar v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad 1 , this Court observed There is ample authority for the position that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amounts of cash received during the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipts are of an assessable nature.
